### `r row_height(900)`

#### **`r poster_title`**

| Luke W Johnston, Clemens Wittenbecher, Helene T Vistisen, Christina C Dahm, Daniel R Witte
| 1. *Steno Diabetes Center Aarhus*, 2. *Aarhus University*, 3. *Harvard University*

### Background

- Short adult leg length (LL): marker of early childhood conditions and 
associated with higher risk for type 2 diabetes. 
- Not known how association is metabolically mediated.
- *Aim*: Identify how components of stature influence metabolic profile
and consequent risk for diabetes through HbA1c.

### Materials and methods

- Cross-sectional analysis of UK Biobank: n=367,838 (176,420 men, 191,418 women),
excluding prevalent diabetes cases. 
- Applied causal structure learning algorithm NetCoupler
([github.com/NetCoupler](https://github.com/NetCoupler/NetCoupler)):
identifies most likely paths between exposure (LL),
metabolic network, and outcome (HbA1c). 
- Exposures: height, LL, and leg-to-height ratio (LHR)
- Outcome: HbA1c
- Metabolic profile: gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT), alanine aminotransferase
(ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), TG, LDL, HDL, total cholesterol,
C-reactive protein (CRP), creatinine (serum and urine), apolipoprotein A and B,
and albumin
- Confounders: Age, sex, and waist circumference 
- Tested on 100 resamples of 10% of UK Biobank sample

*Results*:

- Metabolic network links: HDL-LDL-Cholesterol-TG (serum lipid profile)
and GGT-ALT-AST (liver function)
- Network to HbA1c: Positive links with ALT, GGT, and CRP
- Stature to network: Negative links between: 
    - LL and height on TG
    - LHR, LL on CRP and ALT
    - LL and height on GGT
- NetCoupler algorithm identified GGT, ALT, and CRP as metabolic link between
stature components and HbA1c

*Conclusion*:

- Findings suggest more adverse childhood growth conditions (resulting in
relatively shorter legs and shorter stature) may contribute to higher HbA1c (and
higher risk for diabetes) through lower liver function (GGT and ALT) and
higher inflammation (CRP).
